properties.media:imagetext:
International Tributes to the History of Flight
First Full-Sized Plane to Leave the Ground
French engineer and flying enthusiast Clement Ader
spent considerable time studying the flight of bats.
Based on his observations, he designed a small-scale
glider with bat-like wings and a tether linking it to the
ground. When that flew successfully, he adapted the
The full-color cachet shows the Eole in flight. Ader
is inside the pilot's compartment, trying to control
the aircraft by flexing the wings. Although that effort
was unsuccessful, the plane remained aloft on its
own for 150 feet.
same design to a larger craft powered by a small
steam engine.
On October 9, 1890 Ader climbed aboard his bat
plane, the Eole, at Chateau d'Armainvilliers, on the
edge of Paris. The plane lifted off the ground and
skimmed along a few inches in the air for about 50
yards. For the first time ever, a powered aircraft had
taken off from a flat surface and flown above the
ground.
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by Central Africa in 1978. It features a portrait of
Clement Ader along with his Avion III, a twin-engine
version of the bat-wing aircraft.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Paris, France
on October 9, 1985, the exact anniversary of the flight
of the first powered plane to leave the ground.
© Postal Commemorative Society
Printed in U.S.A.
2010. 056.007
